docs.lead_paragraph: So now what? The Senate Finance Committee had barely voted on health care legislation when the infinitesimally short attention span of Capitol Hill shifted to the next step. And it sounds like the introduction of a 1950s doo-wop band: Ladies and gentlemen, give it up for Harry Reid and the Bill Blenders.
docs.abstract: Senate majority leader Harry Reid gathers with senators, aides and White House officials to meld Finance Committee's health care bill with legislation approved in July; House Speaker Nancy Pelosi continues to work on pulling together bills approved by three different committees into single legislative proposal for full floor debate; photo (M)
docs.snippet: So now what?      The Senate Finance Committee had barely voted on health care legislation when the infinitesimally short attention span of Capitol Hill shifted to the next step. And it sounds like the introduction of a 1950s doo-wop band: Ladies and...

docs.lead_paragraph: By a vote of 14 to 9, largely along party lines, the Senate Finance Committee passed its health care bill Tuesday after a final debate. The only Republican to vote with the committee's 13 Democrats was Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine. Here is a sampling of noteworthy quotes from the five-hour debate:
docs.abstract: Sampling of quotes from final Congressional debate on health care legislation (M)
docs.snippet: By a vote of 14 to 9, largely along party lines, the Senate Finance Committee passed its health care bill Tuesday after a final debate. The only Republican to vote with the committee's 13 Democrats was Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine.     Here is a...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''This bill is the New Coke of the federal government.'' So wrote Mark T. in a comment to the Prescriptions blog posted as the Senate Finance Committee voted Tuesday. He was not alone in his critical view: Few readers following The New York Times's live blog of the proceedings seemed pleased with the committee's proposals -- or its members.
docs.abstract: Readers' comments from Prescriptions blog and online forum Health Care Conversations in response to passage of health care bill by Senate Finance Committee (M)
docs.snippet: ''This bill is the New Coke of the federal government.''     So wrote Mark T. in a comment to the Prescriptions blog posted as the Senate Finance Committee voted Tuesday. He was not alone in his critical view: Few readers following The New York...

docs.lead_paragraph: It was just after midnight on the last night of the Finance Committee's public debate on the big health insurance legislation. And Senator John Ensign, Republican of Nevada, was readying a rhetorical assault on an amendment put forward by Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, Democrat of West Virginia.

headline.main: Behind the 14-9 Vote, a 24/7 Committee Staff

docs.abstract: The Senate Finance Committee offered a rare glimpse into the hidden world of Congressional staffers.
docs.snippet: The Senate Finance Committee offered a rare glimpse into the hidden world of Congressional staffers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:45 p.m. | Tonight was the first of two hourlong televised debates between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. Mr. Thompson is running as a Democrat; Mr. Bloomberg as Republican and independent. City Room live-blogged the debate, sponsored by the city's Campaign Finance Board and held at El Museo del Barrio in East Harlem. Dominic Carter of NY1 News moderated the debate. Updates are below, in reverse chronological order.

headline.main: Bloomberg and Thompson Spar in First Mayoral Debate

docs.abstract: Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg squared off during the first of two mayoral debates, held at El Museo del Barrio in East Harlem.
docs.snippet: Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg squared off during the first of two mayoral debates, held at El Museo del Barrio in East Harlem.

byline.original: By SEWELL CHAN and MICHAEL BARBARO

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Olympia Snowe of Maine ended months of speculation today by voting yes on the health care reform bill before the Senate Finance Committee. She was the only Republican to do so.
docs.abstract: Did the lone Republican vote for the health care bill hurt or help its chances?
docs.snippet: Did the lone Republican vote for the health care bill hurt or help its chances?
